Article.ArticleTitle: An overview of bromate formation in chemical oxidation processes: Occurrence, mechanism, influencing factors, risk assessment, and control strategies.

AbstractText: Chemical oxidation processes have been extensively utilized in disinfection and removal of emerging organic contaminants in recent decades. Some undesired byproducts, however, are produced in these processes. Of them, bromate has attracted the most intensive attention. It was previously regarded as a byproduct that typically occurred in ozone-based oxidation processes. However, for the past decade, bromate formation has been detected in other oxidation processes such as CuO-catalyzed chlorination, SO<sub>4</sub><sup>-</sup>-based oxidation, and ferrate oxidation processes. This review summarizes the occurrences, mechanisms, influencing factors, risk assessment, and control strategies of bromate formation in the four oxidation processes, i.e., ozone-based oxidation, chlorine-based oxidation, SO<sub>4</sub><sup>-</sup>-based oxidation, and ferrate oxidation. Besides, some unresolved issues for future studies are provided: (1) Clarification of the relative contributions of SO<sub>4</sub><sup>-</sup> and Br to the oxidation of bromine for bromate formation in SO<sub>4</sub><sup>-</sup>-based oxidation processes; (2) evaluation of the role of different reactive species in the bromate formation in the process of UV/HOCl; (3) quantification of the dual role of alkalinity in bromate formation during ozonation; (4) assessment of the risks of bromate formation in SO<sub>4</sub><sup>-</sup>-based oxidation processes for practical applications; and (5) exploration of strategies for inhibiting bromate formation in SO<sub>4</sub><sup>-</sup>-based oxidation, UV/chlorine, and metal oxide-catalyzed chlorination processes.
